content.description:
Starts off with a couple of pockets to the left of the crack, and provides a satisfying crimp before moving into some bigger holds. The start can be graded up if you choose to stay to the right of the anchors and tackle the excellent crack. About 600 yards in you will come to a small canyon, where a massive boulder has separated from the main cliff.

This route is set to the very left side of the small canyon. Only 3 draws needed, the first is set a little high and can be set by rapelling, or by climbing on the left side to reach it. It is best to top out or you can use the two bolts set at the top for a rapell.

Ideally you start on the crack in the middle, with some big gaps and nasty little crimps.  Then a little higher you have more crack to work with, but with little around it, and next to nothing for the feet.  For an easier start, you can start on the barn door to the right, and then finish in the middle.

This is in the middle of the bend crack.  The top is easily identified by the two bolts, and there is a trail to the bottom that is easy to find.
2 Bolts at the top or trees can be used to anchor for the top rope.  Some day I hope to bolt this route.

The Climb starts with a beatiful flake to lay back on, and then gets spotty about half way up. Then you can go left for a significant challenge, or right onto the dihedral for an easy finish. About 600 yards in you will come to a small canyon, where a massive boulder has separated from the main cliff.

This route is set to the middle - right side of the small canyon. 3 Bolts, ok top anchors, but easier to top out. The first clip is ridiculously high, and the second clip is only necessary if you go left.
Note that the top of the barn door sounds hollow, and flexes a little. As such, belaying from away and to the right is recommended.

Big holds and several ledges make this walk in the park a satsfying feel good warm up.  The start has a bit of a mantle, and the end has a small outcropping to get over, but otherwise, it is a comfortable dihedral, with lots of options.

In the canyon area of the bend, about 600 yards from the road, tops out at the top of the trail to the bottom.
Top Rope for now, though you can lead it if you use the unusual bolt pattern of the climb next to it.

Several Cliffs overlook the marshes along the edge of highway 11.  South facing, the cliffs have open areas with sunlight, and others that are well shaded.  Intermittent rock faces remain to be explored on the way in, and someone has placed bolts on a cliff top shortly along the trai that I have not explored.  The best climbing is about 600 yards in, with richly textured rock, with pockets and cracks.  There is also some great bouldering to be had on the outside of the canyon area. 
  
 Many of the routes here have been climbed by others, so if you know who ran the first ascent, or what these were called, let us know.
